definition:
A function $f$ is a *one-way function* if for any probabilistic,
polynomial time computable function $g$ and any polynomial function $p$
there is $m$ such that for all $n>m$:

$$\operatorname{Pr}[f(g(f(x)))=f(x)]<\frac{1}{p(n)}$$

where $x$ has length $n$ and all numbers of length $n$ are equally
likely.

That is, no probabilistic, polynomial time function can effectively
compute $f^{-1}$.

Note that, since $f$ need not be injective, this is a stricter
requirement than $$\operatorname{Pr}[g(f(x)))=x]<\frac{1}{p(n)}$$

since not only is $g(f(x))$ (almost always) not $x$, it is (almost
always) no value such that $f(g(f(x)))=f(x)$.
